content: A new proposal has been announced: Tier 3 target proposal: riscv64gc-linux-android (Android target for riscv64gc) #472. It will be announced at the next meeting to try and draw attention to it, but usually MCPs are not discussed during triage meetings. If you think this would benefit from discussion amongst the team, consider proposing a design meeting.
I am not very familiar with the MCP process. In order for this MCP to progress, what should I do in addition to just sit and wait?

Someone on the compiler team needs to second the proposal. The MCP then enters the final comment period. If after it is seconded in the next 10 (I think) days nobody objects, it will be accepted.

cc @Josh Triplett? I see you have been involved with getting new targets accepted in the past.

That proposal looks entirely reasonable to me, and meets all the requirements. I think you just need a compiler team member to notice. You might check if it was discussed in a compiler team meeting already, as well.

Josh Triplett said:

That proposal looks entirely reasonable to me, and meets all the requirements. I think you just need a compiler team member to notice. You might check if it was discussed in a compiler team meeting already, as well.

Thank you! I will take a look.

@liushuyu sorry for the perceived delay, MCPs may take a little bit to get through but they are always on the radar of the compiler team.
The weekly meeting has all MCPs in various stages of progress. Example, this weeks' meeting:
https://hackmd.io/kDUJQbY8SGqPMTTecCl9hg#MCPsFCPs

apiraino said:

liushuyu sorry for the perceived delay, MCPs may take a little bit to get through but they are always on the radar of the compiler team.
The weekly meeting has all MCPs in various stages of progress. Example, this weeks' meeting:
https://hackmd.io/kDUJQbY8SGqPMTTecCl9hg#MCPsFCPs

I see. I could understand that there are far more important items to consider during the meeting.
I asked the question because I was afraid I did something incorrectly and nobody could act upon it.
Thank you for your quick response.
